item.title: Live-Blog the Mad Men Season Premier with Us!
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Joines Schinsky
item.description:
Here at the Riot, we love pop culture just as much as we love books (and that’s a whole lot). Many of us are big fans of Mad Men–last year we recommended books for the characters–so this year we’ve decided to live-blog the two-hour season premier. Don, Peggy, and the gang are coming back this Sunday, April 7th, [...]

item.dc:creator: Rebecca Joines Schinsky
item.description:
This week’s Name Those Authors! is sponsored by The Scorpio Races by Maggie Stiefvater. Some race to win. Others race to survive. It happens at the start of every November: the Scorpio Races. item.title: Ten of the Most Beautiful Libraries Ever Built (In Minecraft)
item.dc:creator: Eric Smith
item.description:
Over Easter weekend, my nephew received a set of Minecraft LEGOs. He was overjoyed, but I couldn’t really grasp his excitement. Lots of my friends play Minecraft, some are hopelessly addicted to it. But me? I never really understood the appeal. So, I downloaded the game on my iPhone, and an hour later, realized I made a [...]

item.title: Little Free Libraries: Building Community & Spreading Literacy
item.dc:creator: Kate Scott
item.description:
Reminiscent of old-style British post boxes, Little Free Libraries have rapidly grown in popularity since their inception in 2009. The movement began in Hudson, Wisconsin, where Todd Bol installed a Little Free Library shaped like a schoolhouse on his front lawn. The idea caught on, a nonprofit was founded, and there are now LFLs in [...]

item.description:
This round of Name Those Authors! is sponsored by Angelopolis by Danielle Trussoni. item.title: Why YA Lit Matters to Everyone
item.dc:creator: Jeanette Solomon
item.description:
Young adult literature gets a bad rap because of the immense, insane popularity of certain titles that book snobs around the globe (including myself, sometimes) deem less-than-worthy of a Serious Reader’s attention. item.title: 12 Alternatives to Goodreads

item.description:
Since last week’s announcement that Amazon bought Goodreads, many of the users over there are looking for alternative book cataloguing/bookish social networking sites. item.title: What to Read Through Your Quarter-Life Crisis
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Joines Schinsky
item.description:
Something happens when you reach your mid-20s. And it ain’t pretty. Your friends start pairing off and getting married and having kids. You might pair off and get married and kids. item.title: 7 Classic Cocktails for Classic Books
item.dc:creator: Community
item.description:
This is a guest post from Shannon McIntyre. Shannon is Southern-born, book-reading, and cocktail-obsessed. item.title: “Game of Scones” and Other Delightfully Edible Books
item.dc:creator: Derek Attig
item.description:
Every year, around April 1, libraries and community groups around the world celebrate Edible Book Day. The main feature of the celebration is usually a lighthearted competition in which contestants use mostly edible materials to evoke popular books. Contestants approach this tasty task in a variety of ways. There are the more straightforward (though often [...]
